articles.title: Daily briefing: Octopus-inspired synthetic ‘skin’ changes appearance on demand
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00080-3A new material can switch from matte to shiny and display a variety of other effects as required. Plus, humans were using poison arrows 60,000 years ago and the quest to authenticate a da Vinci drawing using DNA.
articles.content:
A new material can switch from matte to shiny and display a variety of other effects as required. Plus, humans were using poison arrows 60,000 years ago and the quest to authenticate a da Vinci drawing using DNA.

Hello Nature readers, would you like to get this Briefing in your inbox free every day? Sign up here.

Patterns made on thin polymer films using an electron beam affect how the texture of the surface changes when exposed to water.Credit: Siddharth Doshi, Neerav Soneji, Katie Richards

Researchers have created a synthetic ‘skin’ that can change colour and texture on demand. The material can switch from matte to shiny and display a variety of other effects, before reverting to its initial state. The team used an electron beam to make a ‘landscape’ of bumps on the surface of a polymer that reversibly swells on contact with water. The bumps absorb varying amounts of water, which resulted in a material that could drastically change its appearance when wet. The flow of liquid can be controlled by covering the material with a transparent film.

Nature | 4 min read

Reference: Nature paper

Traces of toxic compounds have been found on 60,000-year-old arrowheads, providing the oldest chemical evidence that Palaeolithic hunter-gatherers used poison to bring down prey. Chemical analysis revealed a compound called buphandrine, derived from the poison bulb plant (Boophone disticha), on arrowheads discovered in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. The use of poisons “shows advanced planning, strategy and causal reasoning” among hunter-gatherers, says archaeologist Justin Bradfield. It also suggests that they had a complex understanding of the properties of plants, says archaeologist April Nowell.

Nature | 4 min read

Reference: Science Advances paper

As mpox continues to spark localized outbreaks in Africa and elsewhere, researchers are racing to understand more about the virus that has caused two public-health emergencies in the past three years. In December, a preprint study found that one mpox strain seems to lurk in the testes of infected male mice. And health officials in the United Kingdom reported that a person had been infected with a never-before-seen strain that is a mashup of two other types. “We should not underestimate what it can do if it’s allowed to become firmly entrenched in human populations and continue to adapt,” says infectious-disease physician Boghuma Titanji.

Nature | 6 min read

Reference: bioRxiv preprint (not peer reviewed) & UK Health Security Agency report

Features & opinion

Scientists have recovered DNA from Holy Child, a more than 500-year-old artwork that is thought to have been drawn by Leonardo da Vinci. After analysis, the team suggests that the DNA could be da Vinci’s, which hints that the artwork is in fact his, and not one of his students’. Their current findings aren’t definitive proof, but could demonstrate the promise of ‘arteomics’, an emerging technique that uses DNA and other biological traces to authenticate artworks rather than relying on expert opinion. If proven to be reliable, arteomics “doesn’t just open a new window, it opens a whole new world” for authenticating art, says chemist Stefan Simon.

Science | 15 min read

Reference: bioRxiv preprint (not peer reviewed)

Last year, scientists conducted a small test of a new, controversial geoengineering technique to combat ocean acidification: pumping the strongly alkaline sodium hydroxide into the water. If kept at a normal pH, the ocean could continue to absorb carbon from the atmosphere, and marine life would be spared the devastated effects of acidification. Early results suggest the method, called ocean alkalinity enhancement, can work, with negligible effects on marine ecosystems. But tackling ocean acidification globally would require the technique to be rolled out on a huge scale, which could have far more unpredictable impacts in the long term, say some researchers.

The New York Times | 14 min read

Rather than wrangling over an ever-changing definition of ‘ultra-processed foods’ (UPFs), policymakers should draw up a universal definition of ‘non-ultra-processed foods’, argue three health-policy researchers. Using this static definition in health policies will make the regulatory decisions surrounding food products more clear-cut and prevent manufacturers from reformulating their products to avoid being designated as ultra-processed. “Instead of encouraging manufacturers to switch one ingredient for another, we need a definition that will incentivize the production and distribution of non-ultra-processed foods,” the authors write.

Nature Medicine | 8 min read

Image of the week

These 773,000-year-old fossils, recovered from a quarry in Morocco, could give researchers clues about the last common ancestor (LCA) — the ancient lineage we share with Neanderthals, whose exact identity has long eluded scientists. Researchers found that the fossils are similar in age to those of Homo antecessor, another proto-human species discovered in Spain, but are morphologically distinct. The age of the fossils fills a crucial gap from around 1,000,000 to 600,000 years ago in which few similar fossils have been discovered in Africa. (Nature News & Views | 7 min read)

Reference: Nature paper

articles.personality_title: New synthetic skin changes color and texture like an octopus
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have been inspired by the way octopuses change the color and texture of their skin to create new materials that can do the same. This ability helps octopuses hide or communicate, and researchers want to mimic it for useful technologies.

**What happened** – A team of researchers developed a synthetic “skin” made from a thin plastic film that can switch between shiny and matte surfaces and change its appearance in other ways. They used an electron beam to create tiny bumps on the film’s surface. When water touches these bumps, they swell differently, making the material look different. Covering the material with a clear film lets them control how the water flows and changes the skin.

**Impact** – This new material can change its look over and over again, just like octopus skin. Unlike many other materials, it can switch back to its original state. This could lead to new products like smart clothing, flexible screens, or surfaces that adjust their look depending on the environment. The control over water flow to change appearance is a unique and simple way to create these effects.

**What's next step** – Researchers will likely work on making the material stronger, faster to change, and easier to produce in large amounts. They might also explore other ways to control the appearance changes, such as using heat or light instead of water. Testing the material in real-world applications will help decide how useful it can be.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists created a new plastic skin that can change color and texture on demand by using water to swell tiny bumps, opening the door to materials that adapt their look like an octopus.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une peau synthétique qui change de couleur et de texture comme un poulpe
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques se sont inspirés de la façon dont les poulpes changent la couleur et la texture de leur peau pour créer de nouveaux matériaux capables de faire la même chose. Cette capacité aide les poulpes à se camoufler ou à communiquer, et les chercheurs veulent la reproduire pour des technologies utiles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe de chercheurs a développé une « peau » synthétique faite d’un film plastique fin qui peut passer d’une surface mate à brillante et changer son apparence de plusieurs façons. Ils ont utilisé un faisceau d’électrons pour créer de petites bosses sur la surface du film. Lorsque de l’eau touche ces bosses, elles gonflent différemment, ce qui modifie l’apparence du matériau. Recouvrir le matériau d’un film transparent permet de contrôler la façon dont l’eau circule et change la peau.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau matériau peut changer d’apparence à plusieurs reprises, comme la peau d’un poulpe. Contrairement à beaucoup d’autres matériaux, il peut revenir à son état initial. Cela pourrait conduire à des vêtements intelligents, des écrans flexibles ou des surfaces qui ajustent leur aspect selon l’environnement. Le contrôle du flux d’eau pour changer l’apparence est une méthode simple et unique.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont probablement travailler à rendre le matériau plus résistant, plus rapide à changer et plus facile à produire en grande quantité. Ils pourraient aussi étudier d’autres façons de contrôler les changements d’apparence, comme la chaleur ou la lumière. Tester le matériau dans des applications réelles aidera à juger de son utilité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des scientifiques ont créé une nouvelle peau plastique qui change de couleur et de texture à la demande en utilisant l’eau pour gonfler de petites bosses, ouvrant la voie à des matériaux qui s’adaptent comme la peau d’un poulpe.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva piel sintética que cambia de color y textura como un pulpo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos se inspiraron en cómo los pulpos cambian el color y la textura de su piel para crear nuevos materiales que puedan hacer lo mismo. Esta habilidad ayuda a los pulpos a camuflarse o comunicarse, y los investigadores quieren imitarla para tecnologías útiles.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores desarrolló una “piel” sintética hecha de una película plástica delgada que puede cambiar entre superficies mate y brillante y mostrar otros efectos. Usaron un haz de electrones para crear pequeños bultos en la superficie del film. Cuando el agua toca estos bultos, se hinchan de manera diferente, cambiando la apariencia del material. Cubrir el material con una película transparente permite controlar cómo fluye el agua y cambia la piel.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo material puede cambiar su apariencia repetidamente, igual que la piel de un pulpo. A diferencia de otros materiales, puede volver a su estado original. Esto podría llevar a productos nuevos como ropa inteligente, pantallas flexibles o superficies que ajustan su aspecto según el entorno. El control del flujo de agua para cambiar la apariencia es una forma sencilla y única.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores probablemente trabajarán para hacer el material más fuerte, más rápido en cambiar y más fácil de producir en grandes cantidades. También podrían explorar otras formas de controlar los cambios, como usando calor o luz en lugar de agua. Probar el material en aplicaciones reales ayudará a ver qué tan útil puede ser.

**Resumen en una frase** – Científicos crearon una nueva piel plástica que cambia de color y textura a pedido usando agua para hinchar pequeños bultos, abriendo la puerta a materiales que adaptan su apariencia como un pulpo.
